results.title: Value analysis
results.creator_credit: Sam Napier-Bell, Leon Clore and Basic Films
results.brief_description: Value analysis is a disciplined approach to cost reduction by the systematic examination and appraisal of the product and its components. Introduced in an engineering company, it emphasises the importance of team approach and describes in detail the various stages of a value analysis investigation. Some convincing examples of reduction in costs through value analysis.

results.title: Valley town
results.creator_credit: Willard Van Dyke and Educational Film Institute, New York University
results.brief_description: The story of how machines made a “boom” town with factories running at top speed, stores crowded with shoppers, money flowing freely - and of how more machines broke it. Considers the problem of capable workers thrown out of jobs because of high-speed machinery. Gives an idea of what this does to the human spirit and of the effect on a family. Finally offers as one solution the constant training of adults to keep them abreast of new developments ready for new and better jobs. Narrated by Ray Collins.

results.title: Valley of the Murray River. Part 3
results.brief_description: In this final film of a three-part series, the Murray River is followed to the more northern and drier area where the annual rainfall ranges from ten to eighteen inches. This area is known as the Mallee and is a region of dry, red soil and stunted growth. Cleared and irrigated it is an area of productive farmlands and well-kept orchards, with its eastern section producing much of Victoria’s wheat. The irrigation upon which much of this district depends is indicated and the main agricultural pursuits illustrated. These include the citrus and vine-growin areas of Robinvale, Mildura, Merbein and Red Cliffs. The film then follows the river into South Australia and illustrates the industries and activities of the people who depend upon the waters of the river for their livelihood. Little water from the Murray enters the sea. In summer it irrigates the land; in winter it fills the storages. The film concludes with scenes at the river’s mouth at Lake Alexandrina. Commentary by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Valley of the Murray River. Part 2
results.brief_description: This second film of a three-part series continues the description of the country and industries along the Murray, from Yarrawonga to the Swan Hill-Moira region. Diagrammatic maps indicate the extent of the irrigation systems on both sides of the river and show how these irrigation systems are operated and conrolled. The industries shown include wool, fruit and rice growing, dairying, and the raising of fat lambs; together with associated processing industries in the areas of Yarrawonga, Shepparton, Rochester, Echuca, Kerang and Swan Hill. Commentary by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Valley of the Murray River. Part 1
results.brief_description: This is the first of three films that present a survey of the Murray Basin - a basin that includes part of South Australia, northern Victoria, and most of New South Wales, and extends some 400 miles into Queensland - one-seventh of the whole continent. The survey covers both a description of the country and its industries. The film follows the river from its source in the western slopes of the Australian Alps, through the high-timbered country, past the river flats, and on to the Hume Reservoir. The type of country, towns and industries as far as the Rutherglen-Wangaratta region are covered. Commentary by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Valley of the moon
results.creator_credit: Ron Webber, Robert Verrall and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: If there were life on the moon, what would it be like? Here is a film animator’s concept, and stranger beings you never saw. In this moon valley (actually a patch of the Alberta badlands with superimposed animated drawings) the creatures that appear on the scene are unlike any familiar to our Earth-oriented view, and their movements are equally strange. But what they do has a familiar look to it. A film without words.

results.title: Valley of the Derwent
results.creator_credit: Norman Laird and Tasmanian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Derwent Valley combines the beauty of the river itself with prosperous agriculture and many links with Australia’s pioneer days. The tourist is offered cruising, rowing and angling along the river, while in New Norfolk, first settled in 1807, you may visit some of the oldest churches and inns in Tasmania. Eighty percent of Australia’s hops, together with apples, cattle and sheep are produced in the fertile valley. Photographer: Neil Davis.

results.title: Valley of Hope
results.creator_credit: David Bowen-Jones, BBC, Channel 0-28, London Film Productions and UNICEF
results.brief_description: A documentary that looks at the urgent need to introduce a health program to the communities of people who live in the isolated areas of the Andes mountains. These tiny communities have very high infant mortality rates due to malnutrition and frequent infections. With no health workers to prescribe the correct treatments, this pattern continues.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Bowen-Jones, BBC, Channel 0-28, London Film Productions and UNICEF

results.title: Valley of hope
results.creator_credit: A Peter Amavasi and Malayan Film Unit
results.brief_description: A leprosy colony in a Malay valley is developing a community based around not only coming to terms with the disease, but also with integrating lepers back into society through education and work training skills. The film also examines the use of new drugs to combat the destructive physical effects of leprosy.

results.title: Valley of Barossa
results.creator_credit: Geoff Shepherd and South Australian Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: Barossa Valley, often described as Australia’s “Valley of the vine” is one of South Australia’s most attractive beauty spots. Against a background of vineyards and wineries, the various seasonal activities are featured and highlights from the biennial Barossa Valley Vintage Festival presented. Commentary by Peter Ross.
